Holocaust Literature Lesson Plan

Grade Level: 7 to 8 grade

Objectives:

Through the reading of children�s literature it is the hope that seventh grade students will

Gain an understanding of the concepts of diversity, culture, community, prejudice, and human rights, acting morally, and take a stand.

Gain an understanding of the harm caused by prejudice and an ability to confront prejudice individually and as part of community.

Be able to analyze a book for its elements.

Understand the era of World War II and the Jewish experience.

Demonstrate an understanding Holocaust and stand for the truth and tolerance.

Gain interests about literature reading.

Materials:

Hana�s Suitcase by Karen Levine.

Number the Stars by Lois Lowry.

Good Night Maman by Norma Fox, Mazer.

Surviving Hilter: A Boy in the Nazi Death Camps by Andrea Warren.

The children we remember by Chana Byers Abells.

Procedure:

Before the class

Before this reading activity, the teacher makes the classroom library filled with the children books of Holocaust, including the picture books and novels.

The teacher selects the four books that are going to be used in reading workshop.

During the class

Book Talk: The teacher briefly introduces each book and tells students about the setting and relationship to historical events.

Read aloud: the teacher reads aloud the students the picture book The Children We Remember to create the atmosphere.

Ask students what kind of prior knowledge they have by using KWL chart, which including WWII, Hitler, and the Holocaust.

Have students or the whole class determine what will be read and how will they begin the reading.

Reading Workshop: Divide students into group of four.

Distribute new books to students and they can free choose what they want to read and get into the group.

Distribute sticky notes while reading and ask then to write down questions or thoughts they have from reading.

Provide reading time about 10-15 minutes. (Silent Reading and Independent Reading)

Group Share: Students share an interesting excerpt with their group mates.

Personal Time: Students can choose to respond to their book through discussion, writing, performance, etc. or choose to continue reading independently.

(The teacher rotates through one group each day engaging the children in book talks, having students read aloud a portion of their text, providing one-on-one reading assistance, recording information on the reading workshop folder, and providing mini-lessons to groups as needed.)

Engage in discussion during reading of the story and /or after the story has been completed for the day.

Suggest several writing activities that can be accomplished in their journals.

Allow share time for responses.

Provide time for students to reread parts where they encountered difficulty with after sharing from journals.

Determine what will be read in the next sitting.

After reading

1. The whole class does the book talk together and share.

2. Ask students to create a story or character map form their assign books.

3. Discuss together why and how the maps are constructed.

Assessment

Personal Assessment: Book report

Students will write a book report about what they read based on the following elements

Discuss the setting of the book

Give a summary of the book by discussing the real person's lives.

Discuss the character/person's traits and support them with examples from the book.

Discuss the theme - the message of the book and some interesting facts you learned from this book.

Personal connection: such as

*What part of the book affected you and in what way?

*Do you think the book gave an honest account of the person's life?

*Do you admire any of the people in the book? Why?

Group Assessment:

students have to explore the time and place based on the books they read independently, and then by cooperative learning do the following assessments.:

-----Mapping the countries involved in World War II

-----Conclude Jewish Experience in World War II

-----Make a Contrast chart from different perspective in terms of this history event

Assignment:

1. Write a letter to a friend expressing feeling they might have as they read the book.

2. Choose one of the books related to Holocaust from classroom library.

3. Do the research from Internet or library about the history of Holocaust.

4. The teacher plans to have a field trip to the Holocaust museum.
